comments.commentBody:
Creeping towards Stiglitz?

I don't blame you. Fiscal and monetary expansion may be necessary, but any such expansion is going to be curbed by our high income disparity.

We need to increase the minimum wage, and to promote union participation, and higher marginal rates on high levels of income. That is the long run recipe for success.

We will continue to have anemic growth as long as we have this current level of inequality.

Apple does not sell its products at a price set by cost of manufacturing and competition.  As Prof. Krugman notes, and you must know as well, Apple sells its products for whatever we are willing to pay, which is a lot.  It may not be a monopoly in the old Standard Oil sense, but it may as well be because its prices are set as if it were.  I think that is the point of Prof. Krugman's criticism.
Your last complaint sounds alarmingly Liberal.  Oh, oh!
Just to clarify, a PIN-only debit card will not have a Visa or Mastercard logo.

There's no question that credit and the notion of easy money is mostly a fool's game. Just look at the statistics of debt levels for the average American household. I've been rooked into it before and it makes me sick to think how much interest I've forked over to the banks for mostly no good reason.

I admonish those teens who are understanding how the world of American finance is completely rigged to put them into debt-slavery to become evangelists about it and tell their friends.

Not only do they not need credit cards, it also forces the excessive American consumerism to the sidelines.

i have traveled to many countries and rented cars without a credit card.  i have only used debit cards for almost 15 years without any real difficulty.  of course i also keep a reasonable balance in my accounts to cover possible emergencies.
I didn't see anyone mention it, but anyone who travels needs at least one credit card.  Has anyone tried to rent a car without a credit card?  What about emergencies away from home?

Um, I happen to have a credit card through my credit union. In fact, part of the reason I still have a distant credit union account is due to the ease of direct deposit, purchases on the CC, and paying the CC remotely. Credit unions have their benefits, but they are still a part of the financial system. I still prefer using the CC over a debit card due to the grand tangles that are caused by debit card errors or fraud. Nothing quite so fun as having your bank account emptied... and it taking 3-6 weeks to have the fraud corrected.

With a credit card problem? Write a note and use cash/checks until it gets straightened out. It's perfectly reasonable to use one responsibly, particularly for larger purchases or travel, if you're comfortable doing so. Using it for coffee? Far less reasonable.

The credit card system is a tax on the economy that goes to banks. Merchants pay each time you use a credit card, it raises prices. It's great not to pay a penny if your card is stolen and used for a buying spree. But it's not free lunch, we are being insured by the banks who get the money from fees, service charges, ATM charges, etc. There's no transparency of any kind, you can't follow the money.

If you pay your balance in full you're unaware of the punitive costs associated with falling behind for any reason. But things happen to the righteous. Illness happens, a large percentage of bankruptcies are medical bankruptcies. Not finding a job that pays enough to deal with student loans happens. Young people are smart to reduce their debt and to try to only buy what they can pay for (that's the point of using a debit card). Credit unions are what banks used to be. Dump your bank and move to a credit union.

"our people are our biggest asset".

Indeed. Any time we need to boost our stock price, we just liquidate a few of these assets.

This seems to be the curse of American-style capitalism: people are to be used rather than valued as resources.

While NOT an economist, after 62 years I've become a good observer. In this nation EVERYTHING hinges on the Dow going up. Whatever pension plans are left (and they get fewer and fewer after the abuses at Ling-Temco-Vought in the 1960s) depend on investments to pay the benefits. So do insurers. The value of a company is not what it does or sells but in its stock price and dividend income. The actual people who perform the work are not figured into it, nor, often, is the quality of the product.

The point that gets missed over and over again is that, in my opinion, there is no value in anything unless someone puts  labor into it to make it valuable.  Gold, diamonds, worthless unless someone digs them up and does the work to refine, cut, mold, polish, or whatever.  The labor force needs to recognize their power and understand that labor is the only true source of value.  What would happen if every single non-management worker decided to sit out a day, a week of work.  Not most, everybody!  What would happen to profits and the Dow then?

It wasn't that long ago that the business world mantra was 'our people are our biggest asset'.   And now the workers are the enemy.  They are pressed to work more hours for less money and made aware at every turn that they are expendable.  So there are more workers than jobs.  So what?   Where is the humanity?  The community?  The quality of life as a result of profit rather than the victim of profit?

SAS -- what do you mean, irreversible?  I think the point people are making well here is that trying things out, both good and bad, is how kids figure out who they are.  Sometimes they're influenced to go with the crowd and sometimes against it.  But over time they gravitate to the things they like themselves.  They need the experimentation, and they need the time, and they need the room to make mistakes.  They don't need someone telling them that decisions they make about 4th grade math class are going to define the rest of their opportunities in life.
Not enough and too many.

Here is research question that you might pursue or persuade some student of economics in a college to pursue:  If Gov. Rick Perry, in his last election, had received ONLY the votes of owners of small businesses registered in Texas, including top management of those businesses, plus the votes of top management of all corporations doing business in Texas, how many votes would he have received?

36 minutes - I got hung up at the northeast - I had Carl instead of Earl Monroe, didn't get SMA, put Mars and Ares in the wrong places, and had May instead of May.

I had DAD instead of DON which took me awhile to sort out, then antibody and horrors became clear. And now off to sleep.

I'll never forget voting against Silber (a nutcase) and having the governor (I think it was Weld) get rid of all the rural ratcatchers. Seemed a good metaphor for what the Republicans are fond of doing - getting rid of any measures to cut back on vermin!

That was the last time I voted Republican; I don't think compassion is growing on the right, quite the reverse.

Please re-read the clue:

Element with a low atomic number that is not found naturally on Earth

There's no mention in the clue of it being in a "pure" or "elemental" form. Boron IS found "naturally" on Earth, unlike, for example, non-naturally occurring elements that are synthesized, such as technetium (43) or promethium (61).

This clue is badly worded and shouldn't have made it into print.

The Westinghouse AP-1000 is semi-factory built. There are factories which make components up to the size practicable to transport. There is a module assembly building constructed at the worksite and removed when construction is finished. The components are assembled there into muti-ton modules which the very large construction crane hoisted into place. The final connection of the modules is not in a factory but in the containment structure of the reactor.

There are plans for four different Gen III+ LWR small modular reactors. All four designs are small enough to completely assemble in a factory and ship by rail to the generating station site; one is small enough to ship by a 2 lane wide truck. The first two of these designs will be submitted to NRC for a type license in 2014.
Thank you for those incredible quote, and your own.

These 'takers' at the top of the 'socio-economic ladder' ought to be giving back as much as they are taking. There is much the rich can do uplift society. They can create endowments, support universities, and in general their money could go where it serves to benefit the people. ( Those who support them with the money they pay for their goods and services, should expect better of the 1%. )

We ask whether this is happening as much as it used to. There being so much more money now in the hands of the very rich, we see how they are instead giving back far less, nothing like the proportion of their money they used to give back to benefit the country. By asking that they pay more in taxes, and in higher wages too, are we forgetting how those at the lower end, in whatever ways they give back for the benefit of America, cannot
replace whatever the richest 1% at least could to give back to America, if they chose to ?

What gives any incentive to the rich anymore, to be anything but greedy?
It is sorry testimony to the U.S. how narcissism and selfishness has been ruining the nation.
John F. Kennedy said: "My fellow Americans, ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country." No one anymore, the rich nor the poor nor in between, seems to be doing that.

Lincoln rightly said:
"Labor is prior too, and independent of, capital. Capital is only the fruit of labor, and could never have existed, if labor had not first existed. Labor is the superior of capital and deserves the much higher consideration."

But as Jefferson said:
"Man is the only animal which devours his own kind, for I can apply no milder term to the general prey of the rich upon the poor."

The real 'takers' in our society arent at the bottom of the socio economic ladder, not by a long shot. They are at the top.

Where I live the prices of produce have not been skyrocketing.  While there has been an up and down in prices for milk, for example, overall the prices have been about what they have been for several years now.  Eggs, cheese, milk, lettuce, bread, etc.  No skyrocketing prices here.

Jared Bernstein tells us, "Resources would be much better spent strengthening employer verification systems" than wasted on a surge of spending at the border.

Not one word on proposals now or past (you remember that national identity card demogogued down after Reagan's immigration reform)? Why not throw money away at the border? Why not starve some more grannies and kids to free up $$ for some fat contracts?

Why enact intelligent laws that can register guns like cars, divulge who buys government., raise minimum wages, invest in infrastructure, jobs, education, and earned benefits? Why not enact voting rights and campaign reform like Australia, Canada, etc.? Why not cut costs, instead of cutting health coverage?

Because these would require a representative democracy. Unrigging the game is not a priority for those who've bought U.S.A., Inc.

Instead, monopolists busily obstruct tax reform and regulation, and negotiate monopolies in fast tracked, top secret, so-called free trade pacts, which hardly increase economic growth at all (negotiated by rentiers for rentiers).

Why should Congress listen to your good advice or any other?

Instead, they'll give us more theater, trying to enact immigration law to provide discount tech workers at the mercy of corporate visas, naming post offices, repealing healthcare reform again, or shrinking government down to the size of mandatory invasive ultrasound wands, along with making sure that any regulations or regulators get stillborn.

Here at Washington State University I have never seen such a high demand for B.S. engineering graduates as this year.  That 42 graduations so far.  The state of Washington has to continually import STEM graduates as the state's universities simply do not graduate enough.
It would be better to buy a modular reactor from the US.  The more factory built a reactor is, the firmer and lower the price.  Finland should cancel the bad deal and buy an American modular reactor.

There was this line in my favorite TV drama West Wing, "Who among the 80% will fight for the 20%?" This was said in relation to the character Senator Stackhouse's advocacy of free needle exchange for drug addicts.

So why do we expect that the 1% shall be considerate and benevolent to the wellbeing of the 99%? This is especially when there are many among the 99% who would give away, yes give away freely, their own interests?! This is similar to framing businesses as a civil service or "job makers" rather than an entity to make money for its owners, which they would gladly do with full automation if it is possible.

Just by having elections is not representative of democracy. Democracy does not work without informed participation from the electorate. And without democracy there will be no people's government. Without a people's government, monopoly rents will be the natural consequence.

So again, do point fingers at the 1% and their partners in crime, the corrupt politicians, but after that, please do let us look no further than the mirror.

The comparison was not about the amount of labor needed , but where the labor was paid, i.e., think Henry Ford and the Model T. H.F. realized that he couldn't sell his car unless his own workers could buy some; so he paid his workers more.
If X is the number of people actually involved in manufacturing Apple products, and Y (0.9X {my estimate}) is the number of people working outside the US, then Y is the number implied in the GM comparison.
For GM Y was probably < 0.1X. Whatever the actual numbers, a much larger portion of GM's workers were also U.S. consumers. In Apple's case, in addition to not being in the U.S., I'm guessing most of the people involved in manufacturing parts for Apple in, say China, cannot afford Apple products unless those products are given a hefty discount.

I don't think Apple is a fair comparison to GM of old. The manual labor needed to build a car, before more recent factory automation innovations, is not remotely comparable to an iPad. Even with today's technology it's not comparable.

*sigh* Really? The cultural phenom of the cult of Apple is one thing but the fact remains that the OS is superior and if one uses it to make one's living, obviously and evidently so.

And as a 40-year veteran of audio-visual projection and computer interfacing, let me say that defending the video projector industry isn't siding with the angels. The Mac sometimes requires a simple adapter, NBD.

The last couple of days have told the tale. Investors don't want to invest--they want free money from the FED, and when they have the prospect of not getting it, they run for the hills. What ever happened to earning profits by actually making or doing something rather than manipulating figures and micro-trading?

One would think that manufacturers would understand that people have to have money to buy goods, so there is an incentive in scheduling rising wages--like the minimum wage. But if they aren't making their profits from selling anything at all, who cares if people's incomes never rise?

Apple is not a good model of a real manufacturing company. It is actually not a competitive manufacturer at all. It is a kind of techno-cult. Its legions of customers, glassy eyed,. are convinced that they don't belong to society unless they live in the world of apple equipment. Why should they believe something so ridiculous? Apple product placement is everywhere. It was even in a panel of the newspaper cartoon Judge Parker this week. Take a look. In the movies, on TV every person using a computer or phone is using Apple equipment. That their products are over-priced, frequently unreliable and expensive to repair and replace, and using proprietary dongles and extensions useless for any other purpose never gets figured in to the equation. Go to a meeting and try to connect Apple equipment to a standard projector and see what techno-hassle means.

At least at the turn of the 20th century we had Theodore Roosevelt talking about monopolies and the malefactors of wealth and he was a republican although he called himself a progressive later in his career. He also realized the damage done to working people through the visionary work of friends like Upton Sinclair and Jacob Riis.

Today's GOP wishes that it could return to "The Jungle" by rejecting the social contract and revitalizing survival of the fittest. As we move more deeply into the 21st century, the philosophy of many republicans will be to accentuate this course by taking on 'entitlements' through legal theft of pensions and scaling back access to health care by the poor.

Apple has the mindset that one great innovation by a competitor could be their undoing.  They have piled cash in order to be able to buy any company that has a unique technology they need to stay ahead of the competition.  They also want to be unconstrained in R&D budgeting.  Apple's fear of Samsung, Google and others is not unreasonable.
The only thing that the Mets have to do to get lucky is to play the Phillies every night. I am VERY disgusted.
How can you forget winning in '86 and losing to the Yankees in 2000? For all the suffering that we Met fans have endured, how many times have The Cubs,Padres Astros etc been to the World Series?

Hmmm. You really shouldn't go into the monkey house waving your bananas. The fantasy is always propped up by a crutch called hope. We're past that, really. We just take each day as it is and understand that some of us may not live to see another WS featuring the Mets. Yes, long ago the Mets twice got there almost strictly with pitching, but that was a baseball miracle in '69 and a fluke of the standings in '73. We're not that lucky anymore.
